instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: replacing keyboard a1502 (power button not working)
threads.message:
Hi, I have a rMBP Late 2013 that needs the keyboard replaced. The power button is not working after a coffee spill but the connector and traces are all fine. When I plug in another keyboard it works perfectly fine.
I can't find any videos on replacing a keyboard for this model. I am not sure if the battery will need to be removed in order to replace the keyboard.

If anyone has replaced these and could let me know that would be great

threads.title: replacing keyboard a1502 (power button not working)
threads.message: Yes, battery is partially in the way. I always lift the battery including the metal plate that covers the track pad. Rip out the keyboard and knock the remaining rivets out with a screw driver. That is all the same as on any Air models.

threads.title: replacing keyboard a1502 (power button not working)
threads.message: Since these models have the battery glued on what would be the best/safest way to get the battery lifted off because I don't have an iOpener that ifixit sells.

threads.title: replacing keyboard a1502 (power button not working)
threads.message: Shove something under it. This is not rocket science......Be careful with it though, easy to damage the battery. Best to practice on a case with a bad battery.

threads.title: replacing keyboard a1502 (power button not working)
threads.message: Okay I have another machine I can practice with. I was thinking that I might need to put some hot air on it to soften the adhesive like the ifixit guides say to do.

threads.title: replacing keyboard a1502 (power button not working)
threads.message: Nah, heat does nothing on this adhesive, it will rip apart always.
